column6: Text
George W. Bush becomes President of the United States.
column7: September 11 attacks: Al-Qaeda terrorists crash planes into the twin towers of the World Trade Center in New York City, and the Pentagon in Washington, DC.
column8: A fourth plane is downed on the outskirts of Stonycreek Township, Pennsylvania; 2,996 people die in the attacks.
column9: An earthquake strikes Gujarat, India, on Republic Day, resulting in more than 20,000 deaths.
column10: The War on Terror is declared by President Bush, in response to 9/11.
column11: The media magnate Silvio Berlusconi is elected Prime Minister of Italy.
column12: The United States invades Afghanistan and topples the Taliban regime, resulting in a long-term war.
column13: The al-Aqsa Intifada continues.
column14: The African Union is founded in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.
column15: During an economic crisis in Argentina, the government effectively freezes all bank accounts for twelve months which leads to riots and President de la Rúa's resignation from office.
column16: There are five "presidents" in less than a month.

column6: President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines is ousted.
column7: Steve Jobs introduces the first iPod.
column8: Dean Kamen unveils Segway.
column9: China becomes a member of the World Trade Organization.
column10: Wikipedia is launched.
column11: Eleven members of the royal family of Nepal, including the king and queen, are killed by Crown Prince Dipendra, who wounds himself and dies three days later.

column6: The 2002 Bali bombings killed 202 people and injured 209 more.
column7: The Euro enters circulation.
column8: Riots and mass killings in the Indian state of Gujarat leave 1,044 dead.
column9: Israel starts Operation Defensive Shield in the West Bank in response to a wave of Palestinian suicide attacks.
column10: Construction of the Israeli West Bank barrier begins.
column11: Chechen rebels seize a theater in Moscow.
column12: The International Criminal Court is established.
column13: America demands Iraq allow unfettered access to weapons inspectors.
column14: The Guantanamo Bay detention camp is established.
column15: The Algerian Civil War ends.
column17: The First Ivorian Civil War begins.
column18: Brazil wins the 2002 FIFA World Cup.
column20: Hu Jintao is elected as General Secretary of the Communist Party of China.

column6: The United States invades Iraq and ousts Saddam Hussein, triggering worldwide protests and an 8 year war.
column7: The War in Darfur begins.
column8: The Human Genome Project is completed.
column9: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva becomes President of Brazil.
column10: The Second Congo War ends with more than 5 million dead.
column11: The Second Liberian Civil War ends.
column12: Space Shuttle Columbia is destroyed on re-entry.
column13: The Rose Revolution occurs in Georgia.
column14: The last Volkswagen Beetle is made in Mexico, after 65 years in production.
column15: The first six-party talks, involving South and North Korea, the United States, China, Japan and Russia.
column16: Final flight of the SST (Supersonic Transport) Concorde.
column17: The 2002–2004 SARS outbreak began in Guangdong.

column6: NATO and the European Union incorporates most of the former Eastern Bloc.
column7: Facebook is formed by Mark Zuckerberg, Andrew McCollum, Eduardo Saverin, Dustin Moskovitz, and Chris Hughes.
column8: Union of South American Nations formed.
column9: Madrid train bombings killed 193 people and injured around 2,000, Europe's deadliest attack since Pan Am Flight 103.
column10: The Second Battle of Fallujah occurs.
column11: It is the deadliest American battle since Vietnam, killing 95 troops.
column12: Orange Revolution in Ukraine.
column13: Beslan school hostage crisis.
column14: Boxing Day Tsunami occurs in Indian Ocean, leading to the deaths of 230,000.
column15: First surface images of Saturn's moon Titan.

column6: The Irish Republican Army end its military campaign in Northern Ireland.
column7: 7/7 attacks on London Underground.
column8: Angela Merkel becomes Germany's first female Chancellor.
column9: Tulip Revolution in Kyrgyzstan.
column10: The Second Intifada ends.
column11: Israel withdraws from Gaza.
column12: Cedar Revolution in Lebanon triggered by the assassination of Rafic Hariri.
column13: Second Sudanese Civil War ends.
column14: Hurricane Katrina kills 1,836 people in the Gulf of Mexico.
column15: 80,000 are killed in an earthquake in Kashmir.
column16: The Kyoto Protocol comes into effect.
column17: Mahmoud Ahmadinejad becomes President of Iran.
column20: YouTube is founded by Jawed Karim, Chad Hurley and Steve Chen.
column21: Reddit is founded by Steve Huffman, Aaron Swartz and Alexis Ohanian.
column25: Wedding of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles.

column6: Michael Jackson was acquitted on all charges related to the alleged sexual abuse of a 13-year-old boy.
Independence of Montenegro.
column7: 2006 Lebanon War.
column8: Mumbai bombings.
column9: Comprehensive Peace Accord ends the Nepalese Civil War.
column10: Ellen Johnson Sirleaf becomes President of Liberia, and thus Africa's first elected female head of state.
column11: The International Astronomical Union creates the first formal definition of a planet, and excludes Pluto from the list.
column12: Execution of Saddam Hussein.
column13: The Baiji, the Yangtze river dolphin, becomes functionally extinct.
column14: Twitter is launched.
column15: Former Russian security agent Alexander Litvinenko dies from poisoning in the UK.
column16: Israeli soldier Gilad Shalit was abducted by Hamas.
column20: A coup d'état in Thailand overthrows the government of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra.

column6: Anti-government protests in Myanmar suppressed by ruling junta.
column7: Spike in food prices and subprime crisis help trigger global recession.
column8: Assassination of Benazir Bhutto.
column9: Disappearance of Madeleine McCann.
column10: Gordon Brown becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
column11: First Ivorian Civil War ends.
column12: Introduction of the iPhone.
column13: Virginia Tech shooting.
column14: Chris Benoit double-murder and suicide.

column6: Stock markets plunge around the world, signaling the start of the Great Recession.
column7: End of Monarchy in Nepal.
column8: Google Chrome is released.
column9: Barack Obama is elected as President of the United States.
column10: Dmitry Medvedev becomes President of Russia.
column11: Cyclone Nargis kills 133,000 in Myanmar.
column12: The Gaza War begins.
column13: 2008 South Ossetia war.
column14: The 2008 Summer Olympic was hosted in Beijing, China.
column15: Kosovo declares independence, though it is not recognised by the United Nations.
column16: Iraqi forces crack down on Muqtada al Sadr's Mahdi forces in Basra and Sadr City.
column18: The Large Hadron Collider is completed as the world's largest and most powerful particle collider.
column19: Tesla Roadster launched, the first mass production lithium-ion battery electric car.

column6: The cryptocurrency Bitcoin is launched.
column7: The Gaza War ends while Gaza blockade continues.
column8: The Sri Lankan Civil War ends.
column9: Election protests begin in Iran.
column10: The Second Chechen War ends.
column11: Boko Haram rebellion begins in Nigeria.
column12: Death of Michael Jackson.
column13: Formation of BRICS economic bloc.
column14: Treaty of Lisbon ratified.
column15: 2009 swine flu pandemic began in North America.
column16: Typhoon Ketsana kills 789 people in the Philippines.

column6: After the 2010 United Kingdom general election, David Cameron becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom  A military crackdown occurs in Thailand.
column7: A 7.0 magnitude earthquake in Haiti kills 230,000.
column8: The threat of Greece defaulting on its debts triggers the European sovereign debt crisis and Republic of Ireland's financial crisis.
column9: The largest oil spill in US history occurs in the Gulf of Mexico.
column10: North Korea shells the island of Yeonpyeong.
column11: Gaza flotilla raid.
column12: Burmese political prisoner Aung San Suu Kyi is released from house arrest.
column13: The FIFA World Cup is held in Africa for the first time.
column14: 2010 Moscow Metro bombings.
column15: Arab Spring starts.
column18: The President of Poland, Lech Kaczyński, is among 96 killed when their airplane crashes in Smolensk on April 10.
column19: The Burj Khalifa in Dubai becomes the tallest structure in the world, standing at 829.8 m (2,722 ft).
column20: Dilma Rousseff is elected as the first female president of Brazil.

column6: The iPad is introduced.
column7: Instagram is launched.
column8: 2010 Colombia–Venezuela diplomatic crisis.
column9: 2010 Copiapó mining accident.
column10: 2010 eruptions of Eyjafjallajökull.
column11: Julia Gillard is elected Prime Minister of Australia.
column12: 2010 Mount Carmel Forest Fire.

column6: Independence of South Sudan.
column7: Snapchat launched.
column8: February Christchurch earthquake kills 185 and injures 2,000.
column9: Arab Spring: revolutions in Tunisia, Egypt and Libya follow, as well as uprisings in Yemen and Bahrain, and protests in several other Arab countries.
column10: Syrian civil war begins.
column11: Second Ivorian Civil War.
column12: Occupy movement inspires worldwide protests.
column13: News International phone hacking scandal.
column14: A 9.0 earthquake in Japan triggers a tsunami and the meltdown of the Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant.
column15: The Danyang–Kunshan Grand Bridge, the world's longest, opens in China.
column16: Second Ivorian Civil War ends with the arrest of former president Laurent Gbagbo.
column19: Bombings occur in Russia and Somalia.
column21: Floods in Pakistan, Thailand and the Philippines kill roughly 2,500 people.
column22: Osama bin Laden is shot dead by United States Navy SEALs in Pakistan.

column6: Muammar Gaddafi is captured and killed during the Battle of Sirte.
column7: Wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton.
column8: Gilad Shalit prisoner exchange.
column9: Space Shuttle program is officially ended.
column10: Amazon Rainforest and River, Hạ Long Bay, Jeju Island, Iguazú Falls, Puerto Princesa Underground River, Komodo Island and Table Mountain were named as the world's New7Wonders of Nature.

column6: Northern Mali conflict, the MNLA declares Azawad an independent state.
column7: Yemeni President Ali Abdullah Saleh steps down.
column8: 2012 Benghazi attack leads to the death of US ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.
column9: The Higgs boson is discovered.
column10: Vladimir Putin is elected president of Russia for the third time.
column11: Hurricane Sandy kills 209 people in North America, while Typhoon Bopha kills over 1,600 in the Philippines.
column12: Skydiver Felix Baumgartner becomes the first person to break the sound barrier without a vehicle.
column13: Conflict begins in the Central African Republic.
column14: UN Climate Change Conference agrees to extend the Kyoto Protocol until 2020.
column15: Israel launches Operation Pillar of Defense against the Palestinian-governed Gaza Strip.
column17: The US rover, Curiosity, takes a selfie on Mars.

column6: Barack Obama wins second term as President of the United States, defeating former Massachusetts Governor Mitt Romney.
column7: Shooting of Trayvon Martin: The 17-year-old African-American high school student was killed in Sanford, Florida.
column8: Park Geun-hye is elected President of South Korea.
column9: Pakistani Taliban attempt to assassinate outspoken schoolgirl Malala Yousafzai.
column10: The 2012 Summer Olympics was hosted in London, United Kingdom.
column11: Xi Jinping is elected as General Secretary of the Communist Party of China.

column6: The French military intervenes in the Northern Mali conflict.
column7: Chelyabinsk meteor.
column8: Pope Benedict XVI resigns and Pope Francis is elected, becoming the first Pope from Latin America.
column9: Terrorist attacks occur in Boston and Nairobi.
column10: The Rana Plaza collapses in Bangladesh.
column11: Edward Snowden releases classified documents concerning mass surveillance by the NSA.
column12: President of Egypt Mohamed Morsi is deposed by the military in a coup d'état.
column13: Croatia becomes a member of the European Union.
column14: The Euromaidan protest begins in Ukraine.
column15: A chemical attack in Ghouta, Syria is blamed on President Bashar al-Assad.
column16: A 7.2 magnitude earthquake in Bohol, kills 222.
column17: Typhoon Haiyan kills nearly 6,150 people in Vietnam and the Philippines.
column19: Uruguay becomes the first country to fully legalize cannabis.

column6: Narendra Modi becomes Prime Minister of India.
column7: The worst Ebola epidemic in recorded history occurs in West Africa, infecting nearly 30,000 people and resulting in the deaths of 11,000+.
column8: Euromaidan protest in Ukraine sparks a revolution and the overthrow of Viktor Yanukovych, leading to Russia's annexation of Crimea and the War in Donbass.
column9: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappears from radar while en route to Beijing from Kuala Lumpur on March 8.
column10: There were 239 people on board.
column11: A coup d'état in Thailand overthrows the caretaker government.
column12: King Juan Carlos I of Spain abdicates; his son becomes King Felipe VI.
column13: Indonesia AirAsia Flight 8501 crashes into the Java Sea, while Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 is shot down over Ukraine and Air Algérie Flight 5017 is downed in Mali.
column14: Tehrik-i-Taliban Pakistan kill over 130 students in Pakistan.
column15: Israel launches an assault on the Gaza Strip in response to tit-for-tat murder-kidnappings, leading to the deaths of 71 Israelis and 2,100 Palestinians.

column6: ISIS begins its offensive in northern Iraq, leading to intervention in Iraq and Syria by a US-led coalition.
column7: Second Libyan Civil War begins.
column8: The Rosetta spacecraft's Philae probe becomes the first to successfully land on a comet.
column9: The shooting of African-American teenager Michael Brown by police leads to violent unrest in Ferguson, Missouri.
column10: Joko Widodo is elected President of Indonesia.
column11: Sinking of MV Sewol.
column12: Yeonmi Park delivers an emotional speech at the 2014 One Young World Summit.
column13: The Philippines and Indonesia signed a maritime treaty that draws the boundary in Mindanao and Celebes seas.
column14: Doha, Durban, Havana, Kuala Lumpur, La Paz and Vigan were chosen as the world's New7Wonders Cities.

column6: Five former Soviet Union countries form the Eurasian Economic Union.
column7: A series of terrorist attacks occur in Paris.
column8: Boko Haram perpetrates a massacre of over 2,000 people in Baga, Nigeria, and allies itself with ISIL.
column9: Al-Shabaab perpetrates a mass shooting in Kenya, killing 148.
column10: Houthis overthrow the government in Yemen, triggering a military response by Saudi Arabia.
column11: A series of earthquakes in the Himalayas kills over 10,000 people.
column12: ISIL claims responsibility for the Kobanî massacre in Syria, the Sousse attacks in Tunisia, a mosque bombing in Kuwait, the Suruç bombing in Turkey, multiple bombings in Beirut and a massacre in Paris, as well as the bombing of a Russian Airliner over Egypt.
column13: They also inspire a mass shooting in San Bernardino, California.
column14: Turkey and Russia intervene in the Syrian Civil War.
column15: The heads of China and Taiwan meet for the first time, while the United States and Cuba resume diplomatic relations.
column16: 195 nations agree to lower carbon emissions.

column6: Liquid water is found on Mars.
column7: First close-up images of Ceres and Pluto.
column8: Charleston church shooting.
column9: Assassination of Boris Nemtsov.
column10: China announces the end of One-child policy after 35 years.
column11: 2015 FIFA corruption case.
column12: European migrant crisis.
column13: The Supreme Court of the United States determines that same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry.
column14: The opposition-led Democratic Unity Roundtable wins the most seats in the 2015 Venezuelan parliamentary election, defeating the United Socialist Party of Venezuela for the first time since the National Assembly was established in 1999.
column15: The death of African-American teenager Freddie Gray by police leads to violent unrest in Baltimore, Maryland.

column6: An outbreak of the Zika virus is linked to a cluster of cases of microcephaly.
column7: The United Nations lifts sanctions on Iran in recognition of its dismantling of its nuclear program.
column8: ISIL claims responsibility for a series of bombings in Brussels, a massacre at Istanbul's Atatürk Airport and car ramming attacks in Nice and Berlin.
column9: The Gotthard Base Tunnel, the world's longest railway tunnel, is completed.
column10: The people of the United Kingdom vote to leave the European Union; Theresa May becomes Prime Minister.
column11: Donald Trump is elected President of the United States.
column12: The Colombian government signs a peace deal with FARC despite losing a referendum.
column13: United States troops withdraw from Afghanistan after 15 years.
column14: President of Brazil, Dilma Rousseff, is impeached.
column15: Vajiralongkorn becomes King of Thailand.
column16: The government of Turkey begins a series of purges in reaction to a failed coup d'état attempt.
column17: Rodrigo Duterte becomes President of the Philippines, and initiates a controversial drug war.

column6: Andrei Karlov, the Russian Ambassador to Turkey, is assassinated at an art exhibition in Ankara.
column7: Detection of gravitational waves by LIGO confirmed.
column8: Dhaka attack kills 29 people.
column9: A shooter kills 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando, Florida.
column10: 2016 Southern Taiwan earthquake.
column11: Tsai Ing-wen is elected President of Taiwan.
column12: 2016 attack on the Saudi diplomatic missions in Iran.
column13: 2016 Russian Defence Ministry Tupolev Tu-154 crash.
column14: Radovan Karadžić found guilty of 10 of 11 counts of war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity and is sentenced to 40 years in prison.

column6: Emmanuel Macron becomes President of France after defeating far-right candidate Marine Le Pen.
column7: Tensions between North Korea and the UN escalate as the country tests a hydrogen bomb and conducts a series of ballistic missile tests.
column8: The UN responds with a wave of export sanctions.
column9: A terrorist bombing attack at an Ariana Grande concert in Manchester, England kills 22 people and injures over 500.
column10: Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) launch simultaneous attacks in Tehran, destroy the Great Mosque of al-Nuri in Mosul Iraq, and kill 311 in Egypt, but are declared defeated in Iraq by the end of the year.
column11: A military operation targeting Rohingya Muslims in Myanmar is declared ethnic cleansing by the UNHCR.
column12: A bombing in Mogadishu, Somalia on October 14, kills 587 people and injures 316.
column13: It is one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in modern history.

column6: Hurricane Harvey kills 107 and becomes the costliest hurricane in US history, while Hurricane Irma kills 134, and Hurricane Maria kills 3,059.
column7: Two earthquakes strike Mexico on 7 September and 19 September, killing more than 350.
column8: Kurdistan and Catalonia declare independence from Iraq and Spain, respectively.
column9: Catalonia is not recognised, and Iraq engages the Kurds in conflict.
column10: Robert Mugabe is ousted in a coup d'état, while Ratko Mladić is declared guilty of genocide.
column11: The city of Charlottesville is the site of a far-right rally protesting the removal of Confederate statues throughout the US.
column12: During the event, a white supremacist rams his car into a crowd of counter-protesters, injuring 19 and killing one.
column13: 58 people are killed in a mass shooting in Las Vegas.
column14: Allegations of sexual abuse against film producer Harvey Weinstein lead to a wave of similar accusations from within Hollywood and other areas of primarily the English-speaking world.
column15: Nintendo launches the Nintendo Switch.

column6: Grenfell Tower fire in London kills 72 and injures 70.
column7: 'Oumuamua, the first known interstellar object, is identified.
column8: The President of South Korea, Park Geun-hye, is impeached, while Moon Jae-in is elected president.
column9: A constitutional crisis occurs in Venezuela after Constituent Assembly elections which replaced the legislative powers held by the opposition-led National Assembly.

column6: Turkey invades northern Syria, while 70 die in a chemical attack, triggering a missile strike against Bashar al-Assad.
column7: The Trump administration reimposes sanctions against Iran.
column8: The first monkeys are cloned, and first genetically modified humans reported, in China.
column9: Jacob Zuma resigns as President of South Africa; Cyril Ramaphosa becomes President.
column10: Scott Morrison becomes Prime Minister of Australia.
column11: Four people are poisoned, one to death, in Salisbury and Amesbury, England in a suspected Russian assassination attempt.
column12: The British government responds by leading the international expulsion of 153 Russian diplomats.
column13: March for Our Lives occurs in 900 locations worldwide in response to the Parkland shooting.
column14: The northern white rhinoceros becomes functionally extinct.
column15: The university professor Giuseppe Conte becomes Prime Minister of Italy at the head of a populist coalition.
column16: Pakatan Harapan becomes the first opposition party to assume power in Malaysia since independence.

column6: The first summit between the US and North Korea and the first ever crossing of the Korean Demilitarized Zone by a North Korean leader occur.
column7: Twenty-year Eritrean–Ethiopian border conflict formally ends.
column8: Yellow vests movement becomes France's largest sustained period of civil unrest since 1968.
column9: The Sunda strait tsunami kills 426 and injures 14,000 and the 2018 Sulawesi earthquake and tsunami kills 4,340 and injures 10,700.
column10: Exiled Washington Post journalist Jamal Khashoggi is assassinated inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul, triggering a diplomatic crisis for Saudi Arabia.
column11: Kerch Strait incident triggers martial law in Ukraine.
column12: Macedonia and Greece reach a historic agreement in the Macedonia naming dispute, in which the former is renamed in 2019 to the 'Republic of North Macedonia'.
column13: China's National People's Congress votes to abolish presidential term limits, allowing Xi Jinping to rule for life.

column6: Xi is also the General Secretary of the Communist Party of China, the highest position without term limits.
column7: Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle.
column8: Kivu Ebola epidemic begins in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
column9: 2018 Armenian revolution occurs.
column10: First post-ISIS election in Iraq.
column11: Twelve boys and their football coach are successfully rescued from the flooded Tham Luang Nang Non cave in Thailand.
column12: France wins the 2018 FIFA World Cup in Russia.
column13: Leaders from more than 40 international organizations and dignitaries from nearly 200 countries attends the centennial of the ending of the First World War.
column14: Bill Cosby found guilty of drugging and sexually assaulting a woman and is sentenced to three to ten years in prison.
column15: MIT EAD Airframe Version 2 ion-propelled aircraft launched.

column6: Jair Bolsonaro becomes President of Brazil.
column7: New Horizons takes the first close up image of a classical kuiper belt object.
column8: Chang'e 4 becomes the first object to land on the far side of the Moon.
column9: Protests erupt in Bolivia and Venezuela over disputed elections.
column10: Nursultan Nazarbayev resigns as President of Kazakhstan.
column11: Kassym-Jomart Tokayev assumes power.
column12: Astana is renamed Nur-Sultan in his honor.
column13: Christchurch mosque shootings kill 51 people, while a suicide bombing in Iran kills 41, and a series of bomb attacks in Sri Lanka kills 250.
column14: The Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant loses the last of its territory.
column15: The EU Directive on Copyright in the Digital Single Market is passed over intense opposition.
column16: Abdelaziz Bouteflika resigns as President of Algeria, while Omar al-Bashir is deposed as President of Sudan in a coup d'état amid widespread protests in both countries.
column17: The Event Horizon Telescope takes the first ever image of a black hole, at the core of galaxy Messier 87.

column6: Volodymyr Zelensky becomes President of Ukraine.
column7: Victor Vescovo breaks the human depth record, reaching 10,928 m in the Challenger Deep.
column8: Akihito abdicates as Emperor of Japan; Naruhito becomes Emperor.
column9: Bashar al Assad launches multiple offensives in Northwestern Syria; Turkey launches an offensive into northeastern Syria.
column10: More than a hundred people are killed after police and Janjaweed attack protesters in Sudan.
column11: The United States blames attacks on ships in the Gulf of Oman on Iran, escalating tensions in the Persian Gulf.
column12: Kyriakos Mitsotakis becomes Prime Minister of Greece.
column13: Boris Johnson becomes Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, and attempts a prorogation of Parliament that is ultimately declared unlawful.
column14: Protests begin in Hong Kong over an extradition bill.
column15: India revokes the special status of Jammu and Kashmir.
column16: Barisha raid ends in the death of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.
column17: Wildfires spike in Brazil, while Australia endures the most widespread brush fires in its history.

column6: A major fire engulfs Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris, resulting in the roof and main spire collapsing.
column7: An outbreak of measles and polio is declared in the Philippines, 19 years after polios eradication in the country.
column8: Fossil fragments found in the Callao Cave in the Philippines reveal the existence of the Homo luzonensis species of humans.
column9: The 2019–2020 dengue fever epidemic begins in Southeast Asia.
column10: A 6.9 magnitude earthquake in Davao del Sur, kills 13 people, and Typhoon Phanfone kills 50 people and causes $60 billion in damages, in the Philippines.
column11: The U.S. Justice Department charges Chinese tech firm Huawei with multiple counts of fraud.
column12: WikiLeaks co-founder Julian Assange is arrested in London.
column13: Avengers: Endgame was released in theaters, breaking many box-office records, including becoming the highest-grossing movies of all time.
column14: Isabelle Holdaway is the first patient to receive a genetically modified phage therapy to treat a drug-resistant infection.

column6: More than 50 prisoners are killed in a series of riots in Amazonas, Brazil.
column7: A trilateral gathering was held at the Panmunjom Truce Village between South Korean President Moon Jae-in, North Korean Leader Kim Jong-un and United States President Donald Trump.
column8: Ursula von der Leyen becomes President of the European Commission.
column9: Joaquín "El Chapo" Guzmán found guilty of drug trafficking, money laundering and murder and is sentenced to 30 years in prison.
column10: Japan and South Korea trade dispute.
column11: Sahar Khodayari dies after setting herself on fire after being arrested for attending a soccer game in Iran.
column12: Twelve Catalan independence movement leaders found guilty of sedition and misuse of public funds and they were sentenced to 9 to 13 years in prison.
column13: NASA astronauts Jessica Meir and Christina Koch conducts the first all-female spacewalk outside of the ISS.
column14: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is indicted on charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust.

column6: Sanna Marin becomes Prime Minister of Finland.
column7: Pope Francis abolishes pontifical secrecy in sex abuse cases.
column8: Greta Thunberg delivers "How dare you" speech at the 2019 UN Climate Action Summit.
column9: The President of the United States, Donald Trump, is impeached by the House of Representatives but acquitted by the Senate.
column10: The COVID-19 pandemic begins in Wuhan, China; the start of an ongoing global pandemic.

column6: The COVID-19 pandemic claims 1.8 million lives and infects at least 83 million people worldwide.
column7: The United States assassinates Maj. Gen. Qasem Soleimani, head of Iran's Quds force, in a drone strike.
column8: United States President Donald Trump is impeached and acquitted.
column9: Haitham bin Tariq becomes the fifteenth Sultan of Oman.
column10: The United Kingdom formally withdraws from the European Union.
column11: New Horizons provides the first close up images of a classical Kuiper belt object.
column12: Fears of COVID-19 cause the Dow Jones Industrial Average to fall ten percent in one week, its largest drop in history, triggering the Coronavirus recession.
column13: The United States signs a tentative peace agreement with the Taliban.
column14: Operation Gideon, an attempt by Venesuelan dissidents and an American private military company to infiltrate Venezuela and overthrow President Nicolás Maduro, fails.
column15: Silurian millipede Kampecaris obanensis, the oldest known land animal, is discovered in Scotland.

column6: Cyclone Amphan becomes the costiest cyclone ever recorded in the Northern Indian Ocean.
column7: The killing of George Floyd sparks protests across the United States and the world.
column8: Donald Trump uses tear gas to disperse peaceful protesters in Washington DC.
column9: China's National People's Congress grants itself sweeping powers to curtail civil liberties in Hong Kong.
column10: Manned spaceflight resumes in the United States for the first time since 2011.
column11: Protests begin in Bulgaria against the government of Boyko Borisov.
column12: China and India engage in border skirmishes, the largest escalation between the two powers in 50 years.
column13: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan orders the Hagia Sophia in Istanbul to be reverted to a mosque.
column14: Micheál Martin succeeds Leo Varadkar as Taoiseach of Ireland  Yoshihide Suga becomes Prime Minister of Japan after the retirement of Shinzo Abe.
column15: 2020 Nagorno-Karabakh war between Armenia and Azerbaijan.
column16: The United States formally exits the Paris Agreement on climate change.

column6: Joe Biden is elected  President of the United States.
